You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the industrial production of sectors with higher export shares posted a strong growth in this period.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the relative stability in tourism revenues, the strengthened confidence channel, the favorable effect of the cumulative exchange rate depreciation on net exports, and the normalization of commercial relations with russia will all contribute to growth.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights several positive factors contributing to growth, suggesting a supportive monetary policy stance to promote economic expansion."
}

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in this period, employment increased by 0.3% quarter-on-quarter, while the labor force participation rate decreased by 0.1 points.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:49:07,976 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports a mixed labor market outcome, with employment increasing and labor force participation rate decreasing, but does not provide a clear indication of inflationary pressures or economic growth trends."
}

states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the seasonally adjusted three-month average increases in the b and c indices were measured at 3.4% and 3.6%.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports an increase in the b and c indices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."

inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the annual inflation and the underlying trend of core indicators recorded a small decrease, yet remained high.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, leading indicators imply that the significant slowdown in industrial production observed in july is not permanent.\n                '}]

"justification": "The sentence suggests that the slowdown in industrial production is temporary, implying a potential rebound in economic activity, which may support expansionary monetary policy."

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: prices in other core goods rose 2.66% in line with the last two months, and annual inflation crept up by 0.72 percentage points to 50.1%.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports an increase in annual inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: on the other hand, prices in the restaurants-hotels group surged in january as a result of the rise in the minimum wage accompanied by the recent surge in food prices, particularly red meat.\n                '}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the current level of the commodity price index is 25.6% above the average of the previous ten years.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a significant increase in the commodity price index, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: recent indicators suggest that the depreciation in the turkish lira and the repercussions through confidence channel may lead to a slowdown in domestic demand in the first quarter of the year.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests a potential slowdown in domestic demand, which may justify an easing monetary policy stance to promote economic growth."
}

states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the high contribution from net exports to quarterly growth translates into a growth composition buoying up the current account balance.\n                '}]

"justification": "The sentence suggests a positive impact on the current account balance, which may lead to a weaker lira and looser monetary policy, supporting a dovish stance."

inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: therefore, the outlook for 2019 has been revised down for both advanced and emerging economies.\n                '}]

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee noted that net exports is likely to contribute positively to quarterly growth under these circumstances.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The mid-september, portfolio investments to turkey have been picking up again recently amid reduced geopolitical risks.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:49:44,821 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests a decrease in geopolitical risks, which could lead to increased investments and a more favorable economic environment, potentially supporting a dovish monetary policy stance."
}

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: on the other hand, discounts and campaigns in the last quarter of 2023 and wage revisions in january 2024 have been the factors curbing the decline in demand.\n                '}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3.
